awd_titl_txt: Contexts of Adolescent Ethnic-Racial Identity Development: A Mixed Methods Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Dr. Adriana Uma?a-Taylor at Harvard University, this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist examining everyday contextual influences that inform adolescent ethnic-racial identity (ERI) development. Based on recent projections, no single majority ethnic-racial group will exist in the U.S. by 2044 (Colby & Ortman, 2014). More than half of U.S. public school students are currently from ethnic-racial minority groups (NCES, 2018). These rapid demographic changes will continue to prompt more frequent daily interactions between youth who are different from one another with respect to race and ethnic heritage. Better understanding how diverse youth explore and gain a sense of clarity about ethnicity and race in the context of U.S. society is vital to broaden participation for underrepresented groups. Exploring and achieving clarity regarding one?s ERI is a normative developmental process that positively contributes to adolescents? academic and psychosocial adjustment (Uma?a-Taylor et al., 2014), and serves protective functions for minority youth as a buffer against the negative consequences of discrimination (Yip et al., 2019). Most available research on adolescent ERI has used traditional survey methods, limiting a more integrated understanding of how everyday contextual influences in adolescents? daily lives inform ERI development.  

The overall goal of this project, Contexts of Adolescent Ethnic-Racial Identity Development: A Mixed Methods Approach, is to advance a mixed methods approach to culturally-informed developmental science by offering unique insights into diverse adolescents? routine ethnic-race-related interactions with teachers, peers, and family in daily life. This two-part multi-method study focuses on (1) exploring contextual factors that inform ERI development by learning from group discussions with adolescents of different ethnic-racial backgrounds, and (2) testing how these contextual factors may modify the effectiveness of an ERI-focused school-based intervention program (the Identity Project; Uma?a-Taylor et al., 2018). Secondary analyses of previously collected qualitative data (Uma?a-Taylor & Douglass, 2017) will involve coding ERI-related focus group discussions between adolescents of the same ethnic-racial group, including Asian, Black, Latinx, and White youth. Primary data collection will include twice weekly daily diary surveys as a novel contribution to an ongoing randomized controlled trial of the Identity Project intervention, with the goal of more closely examining daily interactions between students and their teachers, peers, and family as they experience and engage with the intervention content. The study will inform understanding of how such daily experiences can enhance and/or hinder existing and future interventions. Exploring for whom and under what conditions interventions work best is of vital importance to tailor intervention strategies for youth who need it most in the diversifying U.S. school system. In turn, including school-based structured supports for ERI development during the developmental period of adolescence will contribute to broadening participation for historically underrepresented groups in the social sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The first phase of this research project focused on answering the questions: How do adolescents learn about their ethnic-racial identities? In what ways do adolescents’ experiences in multiple social contexts (including with families and peers, in school and in their communities, and online, through other forms of media, and with consideration of the broader sociohistorical context) work together to inform how they learn about and explore their ethnic-racial identities? Findings from focus groups with ethno-racially diverse high school students (i.e., Black, Latino, White, and Asian American) confirmed complex ways in which adolescents learn about their ethnic-racial identities. The study revealed multiple intersections when examining two contexts of ethnic-racial socialization together (e.g., family and community-based settings like places of worship, peers and opportunities to discuss and share in school) in ways that prior quantitative research has not been able to fully uncover. Qualitative coding and analysis for the project involved systematic, iterative, and collaborative consensus-building with a research team that mirrored the ethnic-racial composition of the adolescent participants, a rarity in developmental science research. The results of this study provide important contextual information for ethnic-racial identity-based intervention programs designed for families, community organizations, schools, and peer groups. In line with adolescents’ perspectives, it is critical to identify variability in the barriers and opportunities that exist to support evidence-based efforts that promote the normative developmental process of ethnic-racial identity exploration during adolescence.

The second phase of this research channeled lessons learned from these qualitative findings to design and implement a mixed methods (quantitative and qualitative) daily diary study to amplify the voices and perspectives of adolescents as they engaged with a school-based curriculum focused on promoting ethnic-racial identity development (i.e., the Identity Project; see Umaña-Taylor et al., 2018). Informed by a systematic review of available research using diary methods to study ethnic-racial-related processes in context, 180 adolescent participants completed standard survey measures and novel daily diary reports of their ethnic-racial identity and everyday social interactions with teachers, family, and peers while completing Identity Project sessions in their 9th grade history classes. Prior to this project, the daily diary method has rarely been introduced into the design of intervention evaluations, despite notable strengths of this approach to assess dynamic processes that vary across time and context. The study was also unique given the mixed methods approach to gather quantitative and qualitative data from students, daily diary reports collected in real time on the same days that students completed Identity Project sessions, and a longitudinal pre/post-test design to test intervention effects over time. Findings indicated efficacy of the Identity Project for increasing students’ ethnic-racial identity exploration (the primary outcome) when taught by high school teachers as part of required 9th grade curriculum, and there were similar benefits for ethno-racially diverse adolescents (i.e., students of color and White students, students born in and outside the U.S.). Students’ open-ended responses after each Identity Project session highlighted the central roles of their teachers, family, and peers in supporting the processes of exploring and better understanding their ethnicity, race, and identity.

Broader Impacts: Adolescents are growing up in a world characterized by increasing ethnic-racial diversity and hostility related to issues of ethnicity and race. Ethnic-racial identity development includes the processes through which youth explore, learn about, and gain understanding about their ethnic-racial backgrounds. This project built upon foundational theory and research to advance the study of ethnic-racial identity development as a set of necessary competencies for all youth living in and contributing to a diverse society. Furthermore, given the well-documented ethnic-racial inequities of the U.S. education system that marginalize the identities and histories of youth from ethnic-racial minoritized groups, the results of this project to support and prioritize ethnic-racial identity development through intervention in school identify one way to directly counteract, and in the long-term potentially disrupt, deeply rooted educational inequities. This postdoctoral training fellowship significantly impacted the trajectory of an early career PI, and thereby a large and diverse team of emerging researchers who have collaborated and will continue to collaborate on multiple phases of the project. The PIs’ collaboration on this project prioritized (a) following a team-based approach to deepen and broaden research perspectives that represent the many rather than a select few, (b) engaging in continuous and iterative reflection (individually and collectively) to examine biases and the roles of researcher identities in shaping science, and (c) utilizing diverse research methods to harmonize the strengths of qualitative and quantitative approaches, ultimately elevating insights from youth about their ethnic-racial identity development process in their own voices and situated in the everyday contexts in which they live their lives.
